citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of a new type of aerobic, oxalic acid utilizing bacteria, and proposal of Oxalicibacterium flavum gen. nov., sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Oxalicibacterium flavum sp. nov.
Oxalicibacterium flavum (fla´vum. L. adj. flavus -a -um, yellow, referring to the colony colour)
Cells are Small rods, 0.4 μm wide, 0.9–1.4 μm long.
Motile by means of 1–3 polar flagella.
Colonies on nutrient agar are yellow pigmented, with a lobate margin and a rough surface; diameter is up to 0.5–1 mm after 3 d incubation at 28–30 °C.
Oxalate is metabolized via the glycolate pathway.
In liquid culture, the doubling time with oxalate is 1.1 h.
Optimum growth with oxalate is at pH: 6.9 and 25 °C.
The description of O. flavum is the same as that for the genus and the phenotypical features are listed in detail in the text.
Additional/ other characteristics are: Grows at 30, 37 but not 42 °C.
Growth is observed in the presence of 4% NaCl and 2% Oxalate.
Alkaline phosphatase, esterase C4, ester lipase C8, lipase C14, leucine and valine and cystine arylamidases and naphtol phosphohydrolase activity are present [24].
The polar lipid pattern consisted of phosphatidyl ethanolamine [PE] and two unknown lipid compounds.
Type strain is strain TA17T (= LMG 21571T, = NEU 98T).
Its G+C content of DNA is 63 mol% (Tm method).
Source: Isolated from soil litter close to ice plant (Mesembryanthemum sp.), Izmir-Turkey.
The type strain and additional strains are available from the BCCM/LMG Culture Collections and NEU (Collection of Microorganisms, University of Neuchatel, Switzerland).
